---
title: makeAbortApi
slug: en/v2/api/utils/make-abort-api
---

The `makeAbortApi` function creates an abort signal and its associated abort function.

### Import

```ts
import { makeAbortApi } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/utils";
```

### Usage

```ts
function makeAbortApi(signal?: AbortSignal): [
  signal: AbortSignal,
  abort: (reason?: unknown) => void,
];
```

#### Arguments

##### `signal`

The abort signal to associate with.

#### Return Value

Returns an array with the following order:

##### `signal`

An abort signal. It is not initially aborted.

##### `abort`

Dispatches an `"abort"` event on the abort signal. Optionally takes a single argument `reason` that can be used to convey the reason for the abort through the `"abort"` event.

#### Examples

The following example creates an Abort API without any arguments:

```ts
import { makeAbortApi } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/utils";

const [signal, abort] = makeAbortApi();
abort();
```

The above example is mostly equivalent to `new AbortController()`. The difference is that `makeAbortApi` returns an array instead of an object.

The following example creates an Abort API specifying an associated abort signal:

```ts
import { makeAbortApi } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/utils";

const controller = new AbortController();
controller.signal.addEventListener("abort", function() {
  console.log("controller.signal", this.reason);
});

const [signal] = makeAbortApi(controller.signal);
signal.addEventListener("abort", function() {
  console.log("signal", this.reason);
});

controller.abort("test");
```

Output:

```js
controller.signal test
signal test
```

Abort events propagate from the Abort API to the associated abort signal even if aborted through the Abort API:

```ts
import { makeAbortApi } from "@tai-kun/surrealdb/utils";

const controller = new AbortController();
controller.signal.addEventListener("abort", function() {
  console.log("controller.signal", this.reason);
});

const [signal, abort] = makeAbortApi(controller.signal);
signal.addEventListener("abort", function() {
  console.log("signal", this.reason);
});

abort("test");
```

Output:

```js
controller.signal test
signal test
```
